{{linktext|天|童|宗|珏}} |image= Tiantong Zongjue Zen.jpg |caption = |birth name = |alias = |dharma name = |birth_date = 1091 |birth_place = [[Hezhou]], [[China]] |death_date = 1162 |death_place = |nationality = |religion = [[Chán]]/[[Zen]] |school = [[Caodong]]/[[Sōtō]] |lineage = |title = [[Zen Master|Chán master]] |location = |education = |occupation = |teacher = [[Zhenxie Qingliao]] |predecessor = [[Zhenxie Qingliao]] |successor = [[Xuedou Zhijian]] |students = [[Xuedou Zhijian]] }}'''Tiantong Zongjue''' ({{zh|s=天童宗珏|w=}}; {{CJKV|j=Tendō Sōkaku}}), was a Chinese [[Zen]] [[Buddhist]] monk during the [[Song Dynasty]]. He was born in [[Hezhou]], but left home to practice Buddhism at the age of sixteen. His ordination took place two years later. [[Zuzhao Daohe]] of the [[The Five Houses of Chán|Yunmen School]] was his first teacher. However, Daohe retired and was replaced by [[Zhenxie Qingliao]] of the [[Caodong]]/[[Sōtō]] School, who became the teacher that gave Zongjue [[dharma transmission]]. In 1132, Zongjue became the [[abbot]] of Yuelin Temple where he served for 23 years. After this period, his abbacy switched to Mt. Xuedou. He remained there for four years before becoming the abbot of Tiantong Monastery near the modern city of [[Ningbo]] in 1159.{{citation|last=Ferguson|first=Andrew E.|title=Zen's Chinese heritage: the masters and their teachings|year=2000|publisher=Wisdom Publications|isbn=978-0-86171-163-5}}{{rp|438}} He was replacing the former abbot, the famous [[Hongzhi Zhengjue]], who died there in 1157.{{citation|last=Schlütter|first=Morten|title=How Zen Became Zen: The Dispute Over Enlightenment and the Formation of Chan Buddhism in Song-Dynasty China|year=2010|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|isbn=978-0-8248-3508-8|pages=133}} It was from this final temple, where Zongjue died in 1162, that he took his name.{{rp|438}} Tiantong temple was the same monastery where [[Eihei Dogen]] studied under [[Tiantong Rujing]] before bringing the teaching back to [[Japan]] and founding the [[Sōtō|Sōtō School]].{{rp|454}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{S-start}} {{s-rel|bu}} {{succession box|title=[[Sōtō]] [[Zen]] patriarch|before=[[Zhenxie Qingliao]]|after=[[Xuedou Zhijian]]| years=}} {{S-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zongjue, Tiantong}} [[Category:Zen]] [[Category:1088 births]] [[Category:1162 deaths]] [[Category:Song dynasty Buddhists]] [[Category:Buddhism in China]] [[Category:Chinese Buddhist monks]] [[Category: Chinese Zen Buddhists]] [[Category:History of Buddhism]]

[[File:Timbuktu-manuscripts-astronomy-mathematics.jpg|thumb|A manuscript page from Timbuktu]] [[File:Loc timbuktu manuscripts amm0001rs.jpg|thumb|Manuscript of Nasir al-Din Abu al-Abbas Ahmad ibn al-Hajj al-Amin al-Tawathi al-Ghalawi's ''Kashf al-Ghummah fi Nafa al-Ummah''. From the [[Mamma Haidara Commemorative Library]], Timbuktu.]] [[File:Timbuktu-manuscripts-astronomy-tables.jpg|thumb|A manuscript page from Timbuktu showing a table of astronomical information]] '''Timbuktu Manuscripts''' (or '''Tombouctou Manuscripts''') is a blanket term for the large number of historically important manuscripts that have been preserved for centuries in private households in [[Timbuktu]], [[Mali]]. The collections include manuscripts about art, medicine, philosophy, and science, as well as copies of the [[Quran]]. The number of manuscripts in the collections has been estimated as high as 700,000.<ref name="ngn">{{cite web|title=Reclaiming the Ancient Manuscripts of Timbuktu|journal=National Geographic News|last=Rainier|first=Chris|date=May 27, 2003|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2003/05/0522_030527_timbuktu.html}}</ref>
The manuscripts were written in [[Arabic]] and local languages like [[Songhay languages|Songhay]] and [[Tuareg languages|Tamasheq]].<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/07/world/africa/07mali.html?pagewanted=all] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130129103027/http://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/07/world/africa/07mali.html?pagewanted=all |date=January 29, 2013 }}</ref> The dates of the manuscripts ranged between the late 13th and the early 20th centuries (i.e., from the Islamisation of the [[Mali Empire]] until the decline of traditional education in [[French Sudan]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tombouctoumanuscripts.org/about/project/ |title=Project – Tombouctou Manuscripts Project |publisher=Tombouctoumanuscripts.org |date= |accessdate=2015-05-31}}</ref> Their subject matter ranged from scholarly works to short letters. The manuscripts were passed down in Timbuktu families and were mostly in poor condition.<ref>"Towards an omnilingual word retrieval system for ancient manuscripts". ''Pattern Recognition'' Volume 42, Issue 9, September 2009, Pages 2089–2105.</ref> Most of the manuscripts remain unstudied and uncatalogued, and their total number is unknown, affording only rough estimates. A selection of about 160 manuscripts from the Mamma Haidara Library in Timbuktu and the Ahmed Baba collection were digitized by the ''Tombouctou Manuscripts Project'' in the 2000s.
With the demise of Arabic education in Mali under French colonial rule, appreciation for the medieval manuscripts declined in Timbuktu, and many were being sold off.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uir.unisa.ac.za/bitstream/handle/10500/3686/fundamina%20goolam%20nuut%20Rena.pdf?sequence=1 |format=PDF |title=THE TIMBUKTU MANUSCRIPTS – REDISCOVERING A WRITTEN SOURCE OF AFRICAN LAW IN THE ERA OF THE AFRICAN RENAISSANCE |publisher=Uir.unisa.ac.za |accessdate=2015-05-31}}</ref> ''Time'' magazine related the account of an [[imam]] who picked up four of them for $50 each. In October 2008 one of the households was flooded, destroying 700 manuscripts.<ref name=Walt>{{cite news|last1=Walt|first1=Vivienne|title=Lost Treasures of Timbuktu|url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1924486,00.html|accessdate=4 March 2015|work=Time|date=September 28, 2009}}</ref>
==Research== [[File:Digitizing ancient documents.jpg|thumb|left|Digitizing ancient documents at the Ahmed Baba Institute of Higher Learning and Islamic Research, 2007]] In 1970, [[UNESCO]] founded an organization which included among its tasks preservation of the manuscripts, but it went unfunded until 1977.<ref>[http://www.sum.uio.no/research/mali/timbuktu/cedrab/index.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725060040/http://www.sum.uio.no/research/mali/timbuktu/cedrab/index.html |date=July 25, 2011 }}</ref> In 1998, Harvard University professor [[Henry Louis Gates]] visited Timbuktu for his [[PBS]] series ''Wonders of the African World''. The series raised public and academic awareness of the manuscripts, which led to a pool of funding opening up.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://international.loc.gov/intldl/malihtml/about.html |title=Islamic Manuscripts from Mali - About the Collection - (Global Gateway from the Library of Congress) |publisher=International.loc.gov |date= |accessdate=2015-05-31}}</ref>
The ''Timbuktu Manuscripts Project'' was a project of the [[University of Oslo]] running from 1999 - 2007, the goal of which was to assist in physically preserving the manuscripts, digitize them and building an electronic catalogue, and making them accessible for research.<ref> {{cite web|url=http://www.sum.uio.no/timbuktu/ |accessdate=January 5, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101010024917/http://www.sum.uio.no/timbuktu/ |archivedate=October 10, 2010 |title=Libraries of Timbuktu }}</ref> It was funded by the government of [[Luxembourg]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://portal.unesco.org/ci/en/ev.php-URL_ID=17480&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120715204006/http://portal.unesco.org/ci/en/ev.php-URL_ID=17480&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-07-15 |title=Timbuktu Manuscripts Project Continues with Preservation Study Tours |publisher=Portal.unesco.org |date=2004-11-13 |accessdate=2015-05-31 }}</ref> along with the [[Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation]] (NORAD), the [[Ford Foundation]], the [[Norwegian Council for Higher Education's Programme for Development Research and Education]] (NUFU), and the United States' [[Ambassadors Fund for Cultural Preservation]]. Among the results of the project are: reviving the ancient art of [[bookbinding]] and training a solid number of local specialists; devising and setting up an electronic database to catalogue the manuscripts held at the Institut des Hautes Études et de Recherche Islamique – Ahmad Baba (IHERI-AB); digitizing a large number of manuscripts held at the IHERIAB; facilitating scholarly and technical exchange with manuscript experts in Morocco and other countries;<ref>''Les Chemins du Savoir / Masālik al-Maʿrifa: Manuscrits de Tombouctou: patrimoine partagé / al-turāth al-mushtarak min khilāl makhṭūṭāt Tinbuktū''. Rabat: Bibliothèque Nationale du Royaume du Maroc en collaboration avec l'Institut des Hautes Etudes et de Recherches Islamiques Ahmed Baba – Tombouctou, 13–17 Juin 2005. Workshop, exhibit and catalogue. Rabat: [http://iea.um5s.ac.ma Institut des Études Africaines], Université Mohammed V – Souissi, 2005.</ref> reviving IHERI-AB's journal ''Sankoré''; and publishing the splendidly illustrated book, ''The Hidden Treasures of Timbuktu: Rediscovering Africa's Literary Culture''.<ref>John O. Hunwick, Alida Jay Boye, Joseph Hunwick: [http://www.thamesandhudson.com/9780500514214.html ''The Hidden Treasures of Timbuktu: Rediscovering Africa's Literary Culture''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120515082854/http://www.thamesandhudson.com/9780500514214.html |date=2012-05-15 }}, London: Thames & Hudson, 2008. {{ISBN|9780500514214}}. German translation: "Timbuktu und seine verborgenen Schätze", Munich: Frederking & Thaler, 2009. {{ISBN|978-3894057558}}. See [https://www.amazon.de/Timbuktu-seine-verborgenen-Schätze-Hunwick/dp/3894057556/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1336810411&sr=8-2 Amazon preview].</ref>
Since the end of this project, the cooperation of [[Grand Duchy of Luxembourg|Grand-Duché]] de Luxembourg has funded a new project called ''Timbuktu Manuscripts''. This project aims at protecting and promoting Timbuktu Manuscripts, for economic, social and cultural development of the area. It is implemented by the [[Lux-Development]] agency and the goals are:
#a better conservation of the manuscripts (100 listed manuscripts, 10 described manuscripts, 2 digitalized manuscripts, 10 restored and protected manuscripts) #a better scientific utilisation of the manuscripts #use of manuscripts to promote economic, social and cultural development of the area
Since the events in the [[Northern Mali Conflict|North of Mali in 2012]], the project MLI/015 works with its main partners in [[Bamako]] on result 1. These key partners are the IHERI-AB ([[Ahmed Baba Institute|Institut des Hautes Etudes et de Recherche Islamique Ahmed Baba]]) and the SAVAMA DCI ([[Association de Sauvegarde et de Mise en Valeur des Manuscrits et de Défense de la Culture Islamique]]). Beginning of 2013, they had completed an important work of describing 10,000 manuscripts through standardized registration forms.
The ''Timbuktu Manuscripts Project'' is a separate project run by the [[University of Cape Town]]. In a partnership with the [[government of South Africa]], which contributed to the Timbuktu trust fund, this project is the first official cultural project of the [[New Partnership for Africa's Development]]. It was founded in 2003 and is ongoing. They released a report on the project in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ajol.info/index.php/tvl/article/view/29826 |title=Towards a conceptualization of the study of Africa's indigenous manuscript heritage and tradition | Minicka | Tydskrif vir letterkunde |publisher=Ajol.info |date=2008-03-05 |accessdate=2015-05-31}}</ref> As well as preserving the manuscripts, the Cape Town project also aims to make access to public and private libraries around Timbuktu more widely available. The project's online database is accessible to researchers only. In 2015 it was announced that the Timbuktu trust fund would close after receiving no more funds from the South African government.<ref name="tl_sand">{{cite web | url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/politics/2015/01/01/sands-of-indifference-bury-mbeki-s-timbuktu-dream | title=Sands of indifference bury Mbeki's Timbuktu dream | publisher=Times Live | accessdate=2 January 2015}}</ref>
A book about Timbuktu, published in 2008, contains a chapter with some discussions of a few of the texts.<ref>{{Cite book|last1=Jeppie|first1=Shamil|last2=Diagne|first2=Souleymane Bachir|title=The Meanings of Timbukt|date=2008|publisher=[[Human Sciences Research Council (South Africa)|HSRC]]|location=Cape Town|isbn=978-0-7969-2204-5|url=http://www.hsrcpress.ac.za/product.php?productid=2216&freedownload=1}}</ref>
Digital images of thirty-two manuscripts from the private Mamma Haïdara Library are available from the [[United States Library of Congress]];<ref>{{cite web|url=http://international.loc.gov/intldl/malihtml/malihome.html |title=Islamic Manuscripts from Mali Collection: Home |publisher=International.loc.gov |date=2007-11-19 |accessdate=2015-05-31}}</ref> a subset of these are also accessible from the United Nations' [[World Digital Library]] website.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wdl.org/en/search/gallery?ql=eng&ct=Tombouctou |title=Letter to the warring Tribes |publisher=Wdl.org |accessdate=2015-05-31}}</ref>
==Journalistic coverage== A movie about the Timbuktu Manuscript Project, ''The Ancient Astronomers of Timbuktu'', was released in 2009, with funding from the [[Ford Foundation]] and [[Harry Oppenheimer Fellowship Award|Oppenheimer Memorial Trust]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scribesoftimbuktu.com/index.php |accessdate=January 5, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100502022947/http://www.scribesoftimbuktu.com/index.php |archivedate=May 2, 2010 |title=The Ancient Astronomers of Timbuktu}}</ref>
Also in 2009, the French/German cultural TV channel [[Arte|ARTE]] produced a feature-length film about Timbuktu's manuscript heritage: [https://web.archive.org/web/20090912151942/http://www.arte.tv/fr/semaine/244,broadcastingNum=1016150,day=5,week=38,year=2009.html ''Tombouctou: les manuscrits sauvés des sables | Timbuktus verschollenes Erbe: vom Sande verweht''],<ref>directed by Lutz Gregor / Gruppe 5. The full film can be viewed online: [http://www.lutz-gregor.com/filmseiten/timbuktus-verschollenes-erbe-teil-1-2009/ Part 1] | [http://www.lutz-gregor.com/filmseiten/timbuktus-verschollenes-erbe-teil-2-2009/ Part 2] | [http://www.lutz-gregor.com/filmseiten/timbuktus-verschollenes-erbe-teil-3-2009/ Part 3].</ref> Another film on the subject was also released in 2009, entitled "Manuscripts of Timbuktu. The film was made by South African director [[Zola Maseko]], executive produced by the [[South African Broadcasting Corporation]] and distributed by [[California Newsreel]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newsreel.org/video/THE-MANUSCRIPTS-OF-TIMBUKTU |title=California Newsreel - THE MANUSCRIPTS OF TIMBUKTU |publisher=Newsreel.org |date= |accessdate=2015-05-31}}</ref>
In 2013, BBC Four has produced a documentary called "The Lost Libraries of Timbuktu."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00hkb0z|title=The Lost Libraries of Timbuktu|publisher=BBC4|date= |accessdate=2016-05-13}} Although unavailable at BBC, the movie is available at others online video platforms, as [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yVmHqIyVf4s "Youtube"]</ref>
In 2016, a book about the manuscripts and the efforts to save them in the midst of the assault and occupation of northern Mali by Islamists jihadis, was published. The book, ''The Bad-Ass Librarians of Timbuktu" by [[Joshua Hammer]],<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://books.simonandschuster.com/The-Bad-Ass-Librarians-of-Timbuktu/Joshua-Hammer/9781476777405|title=The Bad-Ass Librarians of Timbuktu|last=Hammer|first=Joshua|date=2016-04-19|publisher=|year=|isbn=9781476777405|location=|pages=|via=}}</ref> provides vivid details about the collection of the manuscripts into libraries, and subsequent efforts to remove them to safety during the dangerous conflict, in which the Islamist jihadis threatened to destroy them.
In 2017, Charlie English published ''The Storied City : The Quest for Timbuktu and the Fantastic Mission to Save Its Past'' which tells in alternating chapters the history of European expeditions (1795 – 1860) in search of the mystical city and the Herculean rescue efforts undertaken by Haidara and others to save the manuscripts from destruction by the jihadis (2012). [33]
==Destruction and evacuation of manuscripts== [[File:Timbuktu-139068.jpg|thumb|left|Empty manuscript boxes at IHERI-AB, Timbuktu]] Many of the manuscripts were reported destroyed in January 2013, along with many other monuments of medieval Islamic culture in Timbuktu, by the Islamist rebels of [[Ansar Dine]] in the [[Northern Mali conflict (2012–present)|Northern Mali conflict]].<ref name=Harding>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jan/28/mali-timbuktu-library-ancient-manuscripts |title=Timbuktu mayor: Mali rebels torched library of historic manuscripts |date=January 28, 2013 |accessdate=January 28, 2013 |last=Harding |first=Luke |work=[[The Guardian]] |location=London}}</ref> The [[Ahmed Baba Institute]] and a library, both containing thousands of manuscripts, were said to have been burnt as the Islamists retreated from Timbuktu.<ref name=Harding/> Journalists, however, found that at least one of the libraries was largely undamaged, and that only a few small piles of ash were present, suggesting that at least some of the documents survived.
[[Aboubacry Moussa Lam]] was a signatory to an appeal to preserve the Timbuktu Manuscripts.<ref>{{cite web |title=Timbuktu Manuscripts in DANGER! |url=http://www.bu.edu/wara/timbuktu/ |website=West African Research Association |publisher=Boston University}}</ref>
A former Malian presidential aide, as well as several other people involved with preserving the manuscripts, said that the documents had been evacuated into a safe location in 2012 before the fighters invaded Timbuktu.<ref>{{cite web|last=Walt |first=Vivienne |url=http://world.time.com/2013/01/28/mali-timbuktu-locals-saved-some-of-their-citys-ancient-manuscripts-from-islamists/ |title=Mali: Timbuktu’s Ancient Manuscripts Are Safe, Preservationists Say | TIME.com |publisher=World.time.com |date=2013-01-28 |accessdate=2015-05-31}}</ref> U.S. based book preservation expert Stephanie Diakité and Dr. Abdel Kader Haidara,<ref name=Hammer>{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-librarian-who-saved-timbuktus-cultural-treasures-from-al-qaeda-1460729998 |title=The Librarian who saved Timbuktu’s cultural treasures from Al Qaeda |date=April 15, 2016 |accessdate=August 14, 2016 |last=Hammer |first=Joshua |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |location=New York}}</ref> curator of one of the most important libraries of Timbuktu, a position handed down in his family for generations, organized the evacuation of the manuscripts to Bamako in the south of Mali.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/05/28/world/africa/timbuktu-manuscripts/index.html |title=Saved from Islamists, Timbuktu's manuscripts face new threat - CNN.com |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |date=2013-05-28 |accessdate=2015-05-31}}</ref> Timbuktu has a long tradition of celebrating and honoring family manuscript collections. It is traditional for a family member to “swear publicly that he will protect the library for as long as he lives.” <ref name="Yochi Dreazen 2013">Yochi Dreazen, “The Brazen Bibliophiles of Timbuktu: How a Team of Sneaky Librarians Duped Al Qaeda and Saved Some of the Ancient World’s Greatest Artifacts,” The New Republic (April 2013), 34.</ref> During the evacuation process, Haidara relied on local families to hide the Ahmed Baba Institute’s manuscript collection in their homes before the texts were ultimately transported to Bamako.<ref name="Yochi Dreazen 2013"/> The evacuation was supported by international organizations, such as the [[Prince Claus Fund]] for Culture and Development, whose initial commitment was followed by financial support from other organisations such as the [[Doen Foundation]] and [[Ford Foundation]].<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.princeclausfund.org/en/activities/more-than-95-of-the-manuscripts-evacuated-from-timbuktu-in-time.html |title= More than 95% of the manuscripts evacuated from timbuktu in time - Prince Claus Fund |publisher=|date=2012-10-12 |accessdate=2016-10-02}}</ref> Abdel Kader thanked SAVAMA-DCI and their partners in a letter for enabling the evacuation of the manuscripts to the cities in the south of the country and supporting their storage.<ref>[http://t160k.org/letter-from-abdel-kader-haidara/ ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130627221305/http://t160k.org/letter-from-abdel-kader-haidara/ |date=June 27, 2013 }}</ref>
[[File:Timbuktu-139084.jpg|thumb|Manuscripts of the Ahmed Baba Centre]] However, once in the south the manuscripts faced new dangers: mold and humidity. Stephanie Diakité and Dr. Abdel Kader Haidara began a campaign to raise money for the preservation of the books including a [[crowd-funding]] campaign called "Timbuktu Libraries in Exile,"<ref>{{cite web|author=y |url=http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/timbuktu-libraries-in-exile |title=Timbuktu Libraries in Exile |publisher=Indiegogo |date=2013-06-20 |accessdate=2015-05-31}}</ref> which is currently hosted by the crowdfunding site [https://t160k.org/campaign/libraries-in-exile/ T160K.org]. Whereas many institutions have provided funding, equipment and/or training, the leading role in all the proceedings is played by the local people.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Russo |first= Maria Luisa|date= January 2017 |title=Contemporary librarianship and special collections issues: a case study in manuscript collections of Timbuktu and other Malian cities |url=http://leo.cineca.it/index.php/jlis/article/view/12136 |journal= JLIS.it|volume=8 |issue=1 |pages= 39–49|doi=10.4403/jlis.it-12136 |access-date=2017-01-22 }}</ref>
